Sports teams in Florida
Club | Sport | League | Venue | Championships ( Years ) | Founded
--- | --- | --- | --- | --- | ---
Miami Marlins | Baseball | MLB | Marlins Park | 2 ( 1997 , 2003 ) | 1993
Tampa Bay Rays | Baseball | MLB | Tropicana Field | 0 | 1998
Miami Heat | Basketball | NBA | American Airlines Arena | 3 ( 2006 , 2012 , 2013 ) | 1988
Orlando Magic | Basketball | NBA | Amway Center | 0 | 1989
Jacksonville Jaguars | Football | NFL | TIAA Bank Field | 0 | 1993
Miami Dolphins | Football | NFL | Hard Rock Stadium | 2 ( 1972 , 1973 ) | 1966
Tampa Bay Buccaneers | Football | NFL | Raymond James Stadium | 1 ( 2002 ) | 1976
Florida Panthers | Ice hockey | NHL | BB & T Center | 0 | 1993
Tampa Bay Lightning | Ice hockey | NHL | Amalie Arena | 1 ( 2004 ) | 1992
Inter Miami CF | Soccer | MLS | TBD |  | 2018
Orlando City SC | Soccer | MLS | Orlando City Stadium |  | 2013

wiki_section_title: Professional major league teams

wiki_section_text: MarlinsRaysHeatMagicJaguarsDolphinsBuccaneersPanthersLightningOrlando CityRams/Chargers ( from 2020 ) Location of major league teams in Florida Florida has teams in all of the major league sports â€” National Football League , Major League Baseball , National Basketball Association , National Hockey League , and Major League Soccer . In the early 1980s , Florida had major league teams in only the NFL . Florida has since added two NBA teams in the late 1980s . Florida added two NHL teams in the 1990s as part of the NHL 's expansion into the south , and two MLB teams in the 1990s . Florida 's most recent major-league team , Orlando City , began play in MLS in 2015 , [ 2 ] and the next , Inter Miami CF , is set to begin play in 2020 .

intro: Sports teams in Florida include many professional, semi-professional, amateur and college teams. In professional sports, Florida has three National Football League teams, two Major League Baseball teams, two National Basketball Association teams, two National Hockey League teams, two Major League Soccer teams, one Women's Soccer team and many minor league teams in various sports. Additionally, since the late 19th century Florida has been a significant spring training destination for Major League Baseball teams and their affiliates.

qa.question: What was the Floridian home arena of the professional major league sports team the Tampa Bay Rays called when it was home to the Tampa Bay Lightning ?

ott_1009_0.Query Analysis: The query asks for the name of the arena in Florida that was home to both the Tampa Bay Rays (a professional baseball team) and the Tampa Bay Lightning (a professional ice hockey team).
ott_1009_0.Query Keywords Extraction: Floridian home arena, Tampa Bay Rays, Tampa Bay Lightning
ott_1009_0.Answer Analysis: The answer is 'ThunderDome', which is the name of the arena that was home to both teams.
ott_1009_0.Document Content Analysis: The document provides a list of professional sports teams in Florida, including their respective sports, leagues, venues, championships, and founding years. It specifically mentions the Tampa Bay Rays and the Tampa Bay Lightning, along with their current venues.
ott_1009_0.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'Tampa Bay Rays' and 'Tampa Bay Lightning'.
ott_1009_0.Key Information Matching: While the document lists the current venues for the Tampa Bay Rays (Tropicana Field) and the Tampa Bay Lightning (Amalie Arena), it does not provide historical information about their shared venue.
ott_1009_0.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not provide the historical name of the arena when it was home to both teams.
ott_1009_0.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides context about the current venues of the teams, which could be useful for further research.
ott_1009_0.Explanation: The document contains relevant information about the Tampa Bay Rays and the Tampa Bay Lightning but lacks the specific historical detail needed to directly answer the query. It provides useful context about their current venues, which could aid in inferring additional information.
